ygData.messageBody:
Who ever says EQ is going down in flames like UO did can kiss my ass....heh.
This is real cool. This makes me want to play more, makes me want to get
into the RP spirit (I admit I have more fun when I RP, which is rare), and
is the best thing I've read on any mailing list in the last month.

Thanks goes to GMs like Brian!

-Leod, Barbarian Shaman, Sterling Order of Knights, Fennin Ro

-----Original Message-----
From: Treadway, Donald [mailto:DTreadway@...]
Sent: Thursday, August 05, 1999 3:45 PM
To: 'EQCheats@onelist.com'
Subject: RE: [EQCheats] Gob Pets in Oasis?


From: "Treadway, Donald" <DTreadway@...>

Sorry, I was in a hurry and didn't disclose my source. Brian Hook posted an
account of the encounter on the errangers list. What I was saying is that
Hast denied that there was any treasure at the time. I didn't say he didn't
tell anyone about it after the fact. And how can you say that he alone
earned the loot of that MOB? There were dozens of people there all helping
to kill the Archon and lesser critters that had been summoned.
Unfortunately, he did not even necessarily do the most damage, since GM
controlled NPC's are open for anyone to loot after they are killed. Here is
Brian's post to the ranger list.

From: "Brian Hook" <bhook@...>

I have some spare time this week, and as such I've been doing some GM events
after hours on various servers (I was Morxxa Mangyfur the Werewolf in SK on
Tunare; the named Archon in Cazic-Thule on Cazic-Thule and Xegony; the
Undead Vizier on the chessboard on Cazic-Thule; Frumpy Darkpaw in
blackburrow on Cazic-Thule), and I've learned some interesting things about
players in general.

First, higher level players are weenies. It's that simple. The minute a
fight turns against them, they're zoning. They're also generally very
stupid the minute something unexpected happens. I was an Archon in
Cazic-Thule and while they were having a picnic in the lower throne room I
popped a justicar, herald, and a champion to liven things up for the
Winnebago crowd.

NOTE: If you are killed by a GM/possessed NPC, you do NOT lose exp!

The zone freaked, had no idea what to do. Some mid to high 40s showed up
and tried to take me out (they were a little, um, foolhardy), doing shouts
of "I'll defeat him!", then -- get this -- sending in their pets ONE AT A
TIME. There was a 50th necro and a 48th magician there, and their pets are
MEAN. But they sent them in one at a time -- easy for me to deal with (I
was a 50th wizzie). If both pets had come in, I would have been toast.

Stupid stupid stupid.

Some of them stormed in, expecting me to be about 35th level, and I nuked
them instantly. So they started whining about it being "unfair". Someone
else in the zone started OOCing how this was "ruining" their evening because
all they wanted to do was get some rubicite and log. Hearing things like
that makes me almost want to give up on the game (or its players).

Anyway, instead of getting organized, they hid in the courtyard. Now, at
this point I had only a small contingent of bodyguards, but more important,
I only had THREE spells memorized -- Ice Comet, Conflag, and Frost Shock.
None of those can be cast very quickly. Two good tanks, two clerics, and
one wizzie could have killed me EASILY, but they refused to come after me.

As I was getting bored sitting with my gorillas in the throne room, I walked
out into the courtyard -- ALONE -- and proceeded to cast, killing a few
folks. Now here's the even sadder part -- I walked out, alone, into a room
of about 20 players from 20th to 50th level, AND NO ONE BOTHERED ROOTING OR
STUNNING ME. They tried to kill me, but instead of taking away my ability
to run or cast, they just tried to kill me quick. Then, even stupider, two
of the casters chased me into the maze...alone.

Dumb dumb dumb.

So I ran back to lick my wounds and hid in the throne room, but they
wouldn't give chase. I finally decided that it was time for me to die, so I
ran to the zone border to kill people looting their corpses (*evil grin*),
and finally I got dropped by a nice crowd.

Okay, so here's the loot I dropped: full set of rubicite and a shimmering
silk robe.

And here's the point where I get miffed: if a GM is killed in an event,
"ninja looting" can happen since ANYONE can loot the corpse, not the
person/party responsible for most damage. A 50th wizard looted my corpse
and got ALL the rubi, then said he didn't find anything. In addition, he
didn't distribute it to anyone else that was in the battle -- he kept it for
his guild (presumably).

This really upset me, but because of a error on my part the two rubi bracers
that were dropped were in a backpack and couldn't be looted (except by me).
I then looted my corpse and awarded the bracers to a 42nd level wizzie that
played smart, fierce, and was RP the whole way. I'm still upset that the
50th wizzie didn't share the loot with the tanks that were there.

At one point a 32nd level SK said something like "Hey lizzie, I'm wearing
your brother as a cloak!" so I teleported to him and said "HSSSS! THEN YOU
DIE!" He was with a party of 30s camping near the Avatar room. He RAN as
fast as he could, but his party put up a REAL good fight. I mean GOOD.
They could have taken me down...almost. I popped an Archon that wasted most
of them, but they nearly killed me. But that party was smart, organized,
and BRAVE. I wish I had caught their names because I would have rewarded
them.

That party of low 30s had more guts and smarts than a whole zone of 40s.
*sigh*

In a way I think a lot of high level players have become used to how things
work, and once things stop working that way, they get really confused and
don't know what to do. I think a PvP player would have done a LOT better.

When I did the event on Cazic-Thule a 32nd level paladin (wearing bronze)
looted me, but since I had an ebony blade on me he gave it to a ranger that
had helped, and he also gave away the rubi pants to another tank. Oh, and
on Cazic-Thule I buffed myself so that basically ONLY melee types could kill
me -- I gave myself insane magic resistance. When I went down on CT server
I was taking about 400 points of damage per tick from 12 melee fighters,
which is EXACTLY what I wanted since I was dropping melee gear. I was NOT
going to let a wizzie get a full set of rubi again.

During another event, when I was the werewolf in SK, EVERYONE kept running
from me for the zone. They kept trying to pull me to the zone so they could
fight then zone if they were getting hurt. I wouldn't play that way, and
summoned a cyclops to help keep the zone clear (MWUHAHAHA).

During the entire SK event, I killed only TWO people. One of them was a
35th level dwarven warrior wearing bronze. He fought bravely -- when I got
him to one bub of health, instead of running he stood up and went down
swinging. Never cried for help, never tried to run. And there was a crowd
around that didn't bother healing him either. This warrior -- Aindolmar --
was an exemplary example of a brave, RPing player. I rewarded him after my
death (I dropped a werewolf cloak and tunic for those that care to know)
specifically with a crafted breastplate. He was wielding a BBC (I think)
and wearing bronze with no other twinks. He wasn't in a guild that I could
tell, and was playing the game "legit" as it were. More important, it
looked like he was playing in the spirit of the game, and I rewarded that.

Finally, when I was the undead vizier on the chessboard, I was a 25th level
wizard. A 15th level dwarven warrior (gotta love those dorfs!) named
Thrombrir kept trying to rally everyone to attack me. A couple druids kept
running from me -- and they were 24th and 37th level respectively -- and
played like complete weenies. This warrior ran up and started whacking on
me, ALONE. No party, no backup, but I was conning BRIGHT RED to him, but he
didn't care. Once again, he was not a twink -- he had on ringmail and some
rawhide -- and he was busy RPing like crazy.

In that battled I dropped an FBR -- which a 42nd level necro looted, as if
she needed it (and I don't think she shared). But I had already learned not
to reward people that looted my body -- too many selfish types. So now I
keep track of players that are brave, smart (if that's in character),
untwinked, and role-playing, and I reward them appropriately after the
battle.

Thrombrir received crafted gauntlets and one crafted bracer to replace his
rawhide.

My point? The lower level types played well, smart, and were having fun,
and the higher levels were busy screaming about things being unfair, were
doing dumb stuff, wouldn't leave the zone border, and wouldn't share loot.
Oh, and when high levels hear about an event via "guildsay", they all come
to kill me so they can get the loot. It's frustrating being a 25th level
mob and getting taken down by a 50th SK instead of a crowd of 20s. But I
can't pick and choose who comes to kill me, so the best I can do is make
sure that the right people are rewarded.

An explanation of my "anti-twinking" policy is probably in order for those
of you in a guild or that are twinked:

- these events are role playing events. All the ones I described I did
alone without any input from others, in an attempt to spice up the game for
some folks. As such, I reward role players.

- I don't reward twinks because, well, they don't need the stuff and often
don't appreciate what they received. There was an 11th level wizzie wearing
an FBR at the chessboard, and I killed him THREE times =)

- the players that really need the gear are often the ones least willing to
sacrifice their ideals (camping/twinking) to get the gear. By rewarding
these players in events like these it spreads good word of mouth, and more
important, instills a sense of faith that they've been doing the right thing
by RPing instead of power gaming.

Anyway, I await your flames :-)

Brian
